title: The Hundred dream team, including Australia, West Indies and England stars
text:
David Warner and Andre Russell have entered the draft for The Hundred (Pictures: Getty)

Chris Gayle or David Warner? Mitchell Starc or Lasith Malinga? Rashid Khan or Shakib Al Hasan?

These are just a few of the questions facing the eight teams competing in The Hundred competition ahead of Sunday’s draft.

Each city-based side will select 12 players – and a maximum of three overseas stars – to fill their 15-man squads, with one England Test player and two ‘Local Icons’ already assigned to teams.

The Hundred: Metro.co.uk’s dream XI

Advertisement

Advertisement

David Warner (overseas, Australia) – £125,000

David Warner is one of the most destructive batsmen in the world (Picture: Getty)

Endured a shocking Ashes series but remains a world-class white-ball batsman, as he showed in last summer’s World Cup, when he scored over 600 runs and three centuries.

Also a brilliant fielder, which narrowly makes him a better option than West Indies great Chris Gayle, who is also priced in the top bracket of £125,000.

Sam Billings (domestic, Kent) – £50,000

Sam Billings is expected to be snapped up at the draft (Picture: Getty)

One of England’s most exciting one-day cricketers and a superb wicketkeeper. Missed much of the 2019 season with a shoulder injury but hit three successive hundreds upon his return to county cricket.

Can bat anywhere in the top six although a role at the top of the order may suit in this shortened format.

Tom Abell (domestic, Somerset) – no reserve price

Tom Abell produced a number of superb innings for Somerset last summer (Picture: Getty)

Enjoyed an impressive T20 Blast campaign for Somerset, scoring over 350 runs at an average of 44.75. A strike-rate of almost 180 also bodes well for The Hundred.

Could conceivably join his Somerset team-mate Tom Banton at Cardiff-based Welsh Fire.

Andre Russell (overseas, West Indies) – £100,000

West Indies all-rounder Andre Russell is a white-ball superstar (Picture: Getty)

A genuine superstar, capable of winning matches with bat and ball. A finer fielder will also be hard to find.

Will not come cheap, having entered the draft with a base price of £100,000, but is worth every penny.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Alex Blake (domestic, Kent) – no reserve price

Kent star Alex Blake could be a bargain (Picture: Getty)

One of the most dangerous players in county cricket, who generally produces two or three match-winning innings a season for Kent in T20 cricket – that will appeal to The Hundred coaches.

Could also be a steal with no reserve price.

Lewis Gregory (domestic, Somerset) – no reserve price

Lewis Gregory will make his England debut this winter (Picture: Getty)

Will make his international debut this winter after earning a place in England’s T20 squad for the tour to New Zealand.

Injuries limited him to just four appearances in last season’s T20 Blast but he is a consistent contributor for Somerset in all formats and will be fit and firing by the time The Hundred comes around.

Samit Patel (domestic, Nottinghamshire) – no reserve price

Samit Patel looks set to secure a contract (Picture: Getty)

Was a contender to be named one of the ‘Local Icons’ for Nottingham-based Trent Rockets but just missed out to England batsman Alex Hales and white-ball specialist Harry Gurney.

Continues to shine for Notts in all formats and helped the county reach T20 Blast Finals day last month before their semi-final defeat to defending champions Worcestershire. A talented batsman and a shrewd spinner.

Ravi Bopara (domestic, Sussex) – no reserve price

Ravi Bopara guided Essex to the T20 Blast title last summer (Picture: Getty)

Wants to focus more on T20 cricket after leaving Essex to join Sussex, so will naturally be desperate to secure a gig in The Hundred.

Advertisement

Can contribute with bat and ball, as he showed on Finals Day when he took two wickets and scored an unbeaten 36 to guide Essex to the title.

Simon Harmer (domestic, Essex) – no reserve price

Essex’s Simon Harmer claimed sensational figures on Finals Day (Picture: Getty)

Also played a starring role in Essex’ T20 Blast triumph, claiming the best figures of any bowler in the history of Finals Day before seeing the Eagles home with a flurry of boundaries.

A former South Africa international, the 30-year-old is regarded as the best spinner in England and would bring valuable leadership skills to a new format of cricket.

Liam Plunkett (domestic, Yorkshire) – £50,000

Liam Plunkett helped England win the World Cup last summer (Picture: Getty)

Will surely attract much interest at the draft as a key member of England’s World Cup-winning squad. His range of skills will be key as teams attempt to limit the inevitable carnage.

At £50,000, would be a cheaper and more sensible alternative to the likes of Dale Steyn (£75,000) and Chris Morris (£60,000).

Rashid Khan (overseas, Afghanistan) – £100,000

Rashid Khan boasts an incredible T20 record (Picture: Getty)

Twenty20 franchise leagues have shown the value of world-class bowlers, so the Afghanistan superstar will surely be the first pick for a number of coaches at the draft.

His T20 record – 269 wickets at an average of 16.75 and an economy rate of 6.24 – is brilliant and gives him the edge over Sunil Narine and Shakib Al Hasan.
